name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

output:

prompt:
Casimir has a rectangle with a checkered area that measures n × m, and initially, each cell in the grid is white.

Let's assign labels to the cell using vertical coordinate i and horizontal coordinate j as (i, j). The cell situated at the top left will be marked (1, 1), and the cell at the bottom right will be marked (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the grid. A tick of dimension d (d > 0) centered at cell (i, j) is formed in this way:

1. To start, the central cell (i, j) is painted black.
2. Then, exactly d cells in the diagonal to the top-left of the center and d cells in the diagonal to the top-right of the center are painted black as well.
3. In particular, all cells with the coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for each h from 0 to d are painted. In total, a tick includes 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that is already black will stay black if painted again. Below is an illustration of the 4 × 9 grid, showing two ticks with sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered grid with the size n × m. Casimir claims this grid is formed as a result of drawing multiple ticks. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is no less than k (meaning d ≥ k for each tick).

Ascertain whether the grid can indeed be constructed by drawing some (or possibly none) ticks with dimensions d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---

The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....

The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed using ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        tick_possible = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            tick_possible[i - h][j - h] = True
                            tick_possible[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        can_form = all(
            grid[i][j] == '.' or tick_possible[i][j]
            for i in range(n)
            for j in range(m)
        )

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if a grid can be formed using ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - k: Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being "YES" or "NO" for the corresponding test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' cells are marked
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - k: Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being "YES" or "NO" for the corresponding test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a tick of size at least k is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed using ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    valid_tick = True
                    for h in range(1, k + 1):
                        if not (grid[i - h][j - h] == '*' and grid[i - h][j + h] == '*'):
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        can_be_tick_center[i][j] = True

        # Mark cells that can be part of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if can_be_tick_center[i][j]:
                    for h in range(k + 1):
                        grid[i - h] = grid[i - h][:j - h] + '.' + grid[i - h][j - h + 1:]
                        grid[i - h] = grid[i - h][:j + h] + '.' + grid[i - h][j + h + 1:]

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        all_ticks_formed = all(grid[i][j] == '.' for i in range(n) for j in range(m) if grid[i][j] == '*')
        results.append("YES" if all_ticks_formed else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, otherwise "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is part of a valid tick
        is_part_of_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if (i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m or
                                grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*'):
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                    if can_form_tick:
                        # Mark all cells of the tick as part of a valid tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            is_part_of_tick[i - d][j - d] = True
                            is_part_of_tick[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid_grid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not is_part_of_tick[i][j]:
                    valid_grid = False
                    break
            if not valid_grid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid_grid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, otherwise "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is part of a valid tick
        is_part_of_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers from bottom to top
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a valid tick of size >= k is found, mark its cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            is_part_of_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
                            is_part_of_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not is_part_of_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, otherwise "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a boolean grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        can_be_part_of_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check for possible tick centers
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m or
                                grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*'):
                            break
                        size += 1

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a tick
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            can_be_part_of_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
                            can_be_part_of_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid can be part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_part_of_tick[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_construct_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be constructed using ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                # Check if the current cell can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                valid_tick = True
                for h in range(1, k + 1):
                    if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
                        valid_tick = False
                        break
                if valid_tick:
                    can_be_tick_center[i][j] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this '*' can be part of a tick
                    part_of_tick = False
                    for h in range(k, n):
                        for l in range(k, m - k):
                            if can_be_tick_center[h][l]:
                                if (i <= h and j >= l - (h - i) and j <= l + (h - i)):
                                    part_of_tick = True
                                    break
                        if part_of_tick:
                            break
                    if not part_of_tick:
                        possible = False
                        break
            if not possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_construct_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - k: Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of strings, each being "YES" or "NO" for the corresponding test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is part of a valid tick
        valid_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells as part of a valid tick
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            valid_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
                            valid_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        is_valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not valid_tick[i][j]:
                    is_valid = False
                    break
            if not is_valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if is_valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a copy of the grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked_grid = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                # Check if the current cell can be the center of a tick
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed
                    if can_form_tick(i, j, k, n, m, grid, marked_grid):
                        mark_tick(i, j, k, marked_grid)

        # Verify if all '*' in the grid can be part of a tick
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or marked_grid[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append("YES")
        else:
            results.append("NO")

    return results

def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], marked_grid: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Vertical coordinate of the center.
        j (int): Horizontal coordinate of the center.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation.
        marked_grid (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    # Check if there are enough cells to form a tick of size k
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - h < 0 or j - h < 0 or j + h >= m:
            return False
        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, marked_grid: List[List[bool]]) -> None:
    """Mark cells that are part of a tick centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Vertical coordinate of the center.
        j (int): Horizontal coordinate of the center.
        k (int): Size of the tick.
        marked_grid (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.
    """
    # Mark the center cell
    marked_grid[i][j] = True
    # Mark the cells in the diagonals
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        marked_grid[i - h][j - h] = True
        marked_grid[i - h][j + h] = True

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Call the function and print results
results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    print(result)

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
